bestBHT.bht: May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. In the midst of trials and temptations, it is our duty to stand firm in the Lord, seeking reconciliation and rejoicing in Him always. This closing statement signifies the genuineness of the apostle's epistle to the Philippians.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: oldest manuscripts read, "Be with your spirit," and omit
Albert Barnes: It is our duty to be firm in the Lord, in all the trials, temptations, and persecutions to which we may be exposed.
It is the duty of those who have from any cause been alienated, to seek to be reconciled.
It is our duty and our privilege to rejoice in the Lord always.
Philip Schaff: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.
John Gill: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ [be] with you all...."
This is the apostle's token in all his epistles of the genuineness of them...
The subscription is, [it was] written [to] the Philippians from Rome, by Epaphroditus...

bhtAttempts.bht: May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. This verse reminds us that amidst trials and temptations, we should stand firm in our faith and rely on the grace of the Lord. It is our duty to seek reconciliation with those we may have become estranged from, and to rejoice in the Lord always. This closing statement serves as a genuineness token of the apostle's epistle to the Philippians.

May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, as we stand firm in the Lord amidst trials and temptations. It is our duty to seek reconciliation and rejoice in the Lord always. The closing statement of this passage serves as a token of the genuineness of the apostle's epistle to the Philippians.

May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, as we stand firm amidst trials, seeking reconciliation and rejoicing in the Lord always. This closing statement serves as a token of the genuineness of the apostle's epistle to the Philippians.
